title: Effect of Concomitant Administration of BMS-708163 on the Pharmacokinetics of Midazolam, Warfarin, Caffeine, Omeprazole and Dextromethorphan in Healthy Male Subjects by Administration of a Modified Cooperstown Cocktail
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine whether BMS-708163 will effect the pharmacokinetics of the commonly prescribed medicines midazolam, warfarin, caffeine,omeprazole and dextromethorphan
placebo: Not specified in the provided description
explanation_target: Reason: The trial drug BMS-708163 is intended to alter amyloid-β production by inhibiting γ‑secretase, i.e., it targets Alzheimer pathology (disease-modifying mechanism) rather than acting as a symptomatic cognitive enhancer or neuropsychiatric treatment. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: I searched for BMS-708163 and found it is known as avagacestat, an oral γ‑secretase inhibitor developed for Alzheimer disease; clinical pharmacology and early trials describe decreases in CSF Aβ after dosing. This identifies the intervention as a small-molecule, disease-targeted agent. citeturn0search1turn0search5

Reflect: Classifying this trial as 'disease-targeted small molecule' aligns with the drug being a small‑molecule γ‑secretase inhibitor aimed at modifying Aβ synthesis (disease pathology). The study title (drug–drug PK interactions using the Cooperstown cocktail) is a Phase 1 interaction study and does not change the mechanism or category. citeturn0search6turn0search2

Web search results (key sources used): PubMed/Clinical Therapeutics descriptions of BMS‑708163 (avagacestat) as a selective γ‑secretase inhibitor developed for AD showing effects on plasma/CSF Aβ. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search5

ClinicalTrials summary of the titled interaction study (Effect of Concomitant Administration of BMS‑708163 on the Pharmacokinetics of ... Cooperstown Cocktail), confirming the exact trial title and that BMS‑708163 was the investigational agent. citeturn0search6
Additional publications and methods papers describing BMS‑708163 as a γ‑secretase inhibitor and its bioanalytical measurement in plasma/CSF. citeturn0search2turn0search4
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug BMS-708163 (avagacestat) is a small‑molecule γ‑secretase inhibitor developed to reduce production of amyloid‑β (Aβ) by inhibiting γ‑secretase-mediated cleavage of APP, i.e., it acts on the amyloid production pathway (disease‑modifying mechanism). citeturn0search1turn0search0

Act: Extracted evidence from the literature and trials: BMS‑708163 is explicitly described as avagacestat, an oral γ‑secretase inhibitor shown to lower CSF/plasma Aβ in preclinical and human studies and tested in Phase 1/2 AD trials. The trial title provided (a pharmacokinetic interaction study using the Cooperstown cocktail) does not change the biological target. Key sources: pharmacodynamics and first‑in‑human PK/PD reports and AD trial summaries. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search4turn0search5

Reflect: The mechanism (γ‑secretase inhibition → reduced Aβ generation) maps directly to CADRO category A) Amyloid beta. There is no indication this trial targets tau, inflammation, synaptic function, or is purely diagnostic — nor does the description indicate multiple distinct therapeutic targets, so 'A) Amyloid beta' is the most specific fit. I reviewed additional analytic/method papers confirming the compound identity and central Aβ effects. citeturn0search6turn0search4

Web search results (key sources used): 1) Multicenter single‑ascending dose study describing avagacestat (BMS‑708163) PK/PD and Aβ effects. citeturn0search0 2) Pharmacodynamics paper demonstrating selective γ‑secretase inhibition and CSF Aβ reductions. citeturn0search1 3) Alzheimer's & Dementia abstracts/papers reporting dose‑dependent CSF Aβ reductions and clinical trial findings. citeturn0search4turn0search5 4) LC‑MS/MS methods paper and analytical studies for BMS‑708163 supporting its identification in plasma/CSF. citeturn0search6
